page.title: 13The Walsingham Shirehall
page.content: The flint_walled Shirehall was part of the medieval Priory precinct.Its first floor hall had an impressive roof covered with Colleyweston "slates".In {1778}it was converted to house the Quarter Sessions dealing with County business and dispensing justice.The facade acquired a new parapet,windows and doors,while internally the first floor was removed and the lofty chamber fitted with a tiny public gallery and cramped benches for magistrates,lawyers and jurors.The accused stood to be tried just a few paces from the lock_up with its barred window,ironwork grille and primitive urinal.The courtroom is very evocative of the {Georgian}era.{ {Quarter Sessions}ceased in{1861}but{ {Petty Sessions}remained until{1971.} The Shirehall then became a local museum.
